title: How to Test Candy Hardness Stages

steps.headline: Learn the different levels of hardness in candy making.
steps.description:
The candy syrup required for a particular candy recipe will be explained by the recipe itself but usually the recipe uses shorthand for what requires a deeper understanding. The different levels of hardness for candies are:
Thread: 106-113ºC/223-236ºF
Soft ball: 112-116ºC/234-240ºF
Firm ball: 118-121ºC/244-250ºF
Hard ball: 121-130ºC/250-266ºF
Soft crack: 132-143ºC/270-290ºF
Hard crack: 149-154ºC/300-310ºF
Caramel: 160-177ºC/320-350ºF.

steps.headline: Test for thread.
steps.description: This has a characteristic of soft, 5-7.7cm/2-3" threads of sugar. Dip the cooking pan into cold water. Lift out a small amount of the syrup and pour it gently over the rim of the teaspoon. Look for a thin thread; if it shows, then the temperature is right.

steps.headline: Test for soft ball.
steps.description: To test for this, dip the pan into cold water. Drop a small amount of the syrup into a bowl of cold water, then roll the syrup into a ball using your fingers. If you find that the syrup forms a ball when in the water and that it is soft and easily flattened under pressure, then it's ready.

steps.headline: Test for firm ball.
steps.description: Dip the pan into cold water. Repeat the process of dropping a small amount of the syrup into a bowl of cold water. Shape it into a ball in the water and take it out. If you find it keeps its shape when lifted out but loses it once it begins to warm up, it's ready.

steps.headline: Test for hard ball.
steps.description: Dip the pan in cold water. Drop a small amount of syrup into a bowl of cold water and attempt to make a ball in the water. Remove from the bowl. If it keeps its shape even when pressed slightly and is still sticky to touch, then it's ready.

steps.headline: Test for soft crack.
steps.description: Dip the pan in cold water. Drop a small amount of the syrup into a bowl of cold water. Pick the syrup up with your fingers and gently separate your hands to pull the syrup. If the pulling reveals a syrup that forms a hard thread that isn't brittle, then it's ready.

steps.headline: Test for hard crack.
steps.description: Dip the pan in cold water. Drop a small amount of the syrup and then take it out between your fingers. Try to break it; if it cracks or breaks and is brittle, then it's ready to use.

steps.headline: Test for caramel.
steps.description:
Dip the pan in cold water. Pour a small amount of the syrup onto a white plate. The colors will tell you all:
Golden honey color: light caramel
Golden amber color: dark caramel
Darker: bitter caramel.

steps.headline: Obtain a candy thermometer.
steps.description: This is a great tool for the avid candy maker and can speed up testing time considerably.

steps.headline: Look for a candy thermometer that shows you the level of hardness marked next to the temperature on the thermometer.
